metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
An attack where malicious scripts are injected into trusted websites.
Victims’ browsers execute attacker’s code with the privileges of the vulnerable site.
Types: Non-persistent (reflected) and Persistent (stored).

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
XSS Example – Reflected
User input echoed directly into response without sanitization.
Attacker sends URL with malicious JavaScript embedded.
Victim clicks the link → script runs in victim’s browser.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
XSS Example – Stored
Malicious script saved permanently on the server (e.g., in comments).
Displayed to users later, executing in their browsers.
Higher impact because every visitor is affected.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Real XSS Examples
Samy Worm (2005, MySpace): infected over a million profiles in less than 24 hours.
VoteHillary.org → Obama iframe injection (2008).
BBC TweetDeck vulnerability causing mass JavaScript retweets (2014).

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Reflected XSS Mechanics
Input → Server → Immediate Response.
Malicious payload delivered via crafted URL or form.
Executed in victim’s browser upon visiting link.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Stored XSS Mechanics
Attacker submits JavaScript to a site that stores and reuses user input (e.g., profile, forum).
Victim views page → script executes in browser.
Results in session hijacking or content defacement.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Consequences of XSS Attacks
• Web defacement (modify page content)
• Session cookie theft and account takeover
• Spoofing login pages to steal credentials
• Self-propagating worms (spread to others)

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Self-Propagating XSS Worms
Malicious JavaScript infects viewers and automatically posts itself to their profiles.
Each new victim becomes a source of infection.
Example: Samy Worm (2005).

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Countermeasure – Filtering
Sanitize and validate user input before display.
Remove or escape JavaScript tags and event handlers.
Example: strip <script> tags from input fields.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Countermeasure – Encoding
Convert HTML special characters so they display as text.
Example:
<script>alert('XSS')</script> → <script>alert('XSS')</script>

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Countermeasure – Content Security Policy (CSP)
Allows only trusted sources for scripts and media.
Blocks inline JavaScript and unapproved content.
Mitigates XSS and clickjacking risks.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Countermeasure – Input Validation
Whitelist expected formats (e.g., email, integer).
Reject unexpected characters or markup.
Combine with output encoding for best results.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Countermeasure – Frameworks
Use secure template systems (e.g., Django, ReactJS, Angular).
They automatically encode user data before rendering.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Practice Question 1
How many ICMP packets (500 bytes each) per second are needed to saturate 0.5 Mbps, 2 Mbps, and 10 Mbps links?
Answer: 125 pps, 500 pps, 2500 pps respectively.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Practice Question 2
Zombie PC uplink = 128 kbps.
How many zombies needed to flood 0.5 Mbps, 2 Mbps, and 10 Mbps links?
Answer: 4, 16, 79 zombies respectively.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Practice Question 3
If we remove the half-open connection buffer to stop SYN floods, will it work?
Answer: No — creates a new ACK flood attack that consumes more memory per connection.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Miscellaneous Attack – Heartbleed
Exploits OpenSSL Heartbeat extension.
Allows attackers to read server memory (SSL keys, passwords).

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Ransomware
Encrypts files and demands payment for decryption.
Examples: WannaCry, CryptoLocker.
Defense: Backups and user awareness.

metadata.file_name: Module 2 - Application and Network Attacks - Part 5.pptx

document:
Cryptojacking
Malicious scripts use victims’ CPUs to mine cryptocurrency without consent.
Often delivered through malvertising or XSS injection.
